Drosophila sechellia is a species of fruit fly that is endemic to the Seychelles Islands in the Indian Ocean. It is a member of the Drosophila melanogaster species group, which includes several closely related species of Drosophila.

Drosophila sechellia is particularly notable for its highly specialized ecological niche and unique adaptations. Unlike its close relatives, D. sechellia is adapted to feed exclusively on the fruits of the plant Morinda citrifolia, also known as the "noni" plant. This specialized diet has led to various physiological and behavioral adaptations, such as the ability to tolerate the toxic compounds present in the noni fruit.

Genetically, D. sechellia is closely related to D. mauritiana and D. simulans, but it has diverged significantly in terms of its genetic makeup and phenotypic characteristics due to its specialized adaptation to the noni plant. Researchers have studied the genomic and developmental aspects of D. sechellia to better understand the molecular mechanisms underlying its specialized traits.

As an endemic species restricted to the Seychelles Islands, D. sechellia is considered vulnerable to threats such as habitat loss and the introduction of invasive species. Conservation efforts and further research on this unique Drosophila species are important for understanding the evolutionary processes and ecological dynamics in this isolated island ecosystem.
